questions.prompt: What is the gradient ∇f for f(x,y) = x² + 2xy + y²?
The gradient vector points in the direction of maximum rate of increase of the function.
questions.explanation: The gradient ∇f points in the direction of steepest ascent, and its magnitude gives the rate of increase

questions.prompt: What is the directional derivative D_u f at a point if u is a unit vector?
questions.explanation: The directional derivative in the direction of unit vector u is D_u f = ∇f · u

questions.prompt: For f(x,y) = x² + y², what is the maximum rate of change at point (3,4)?
The gradient of f is perpendicular to what?
questions.explanation: The gradient ∇f is perpendicular to the level curves (or level surfaces) of f

questions.prompt: What is the equation of the tangent plane to z = x² + y² at point (1, 2, 5)?
The normal vector to the surface z = f(x,y) at a point is parallel to the gradient of f.
questions.explanation: Rewriting as F(x,y,z) = f(x,y) - z = 0, the normal is ∇F = <f_x, f_y, -1>, which includes the gradient components

questions.prompt: For f(x,y,z) = x² + y² + z², what is the gradient ∇f at point (1,1,1)?
The level curve f(x,y) = k represents what?
options: Points where f has the same value k
questions.correctAnswer: Points where f has the same value k
questions.explanation: A level curve is the set of all points (x,y) where f(x,y) equals the constant k

questions.prompt: The linear approximation L(x,y) approximates f(x,y) near point (a,b) using what geometric object?
questions.explanation: The linear approximation is the tangent plane to the surface z = f(x,y) at the point

questions.prompt: At what angle to the gradient is the directional derivative zero?
questions.explanation: D_u f = ∇f · u = |∇f||u|cos(θ) = 0 when θ = 90°, meaning u is perpendicular to ∇f

questions.prompt: For f(x,y) = xe^y, what is the directional derivative at (1,0) in the direction of u = <3/5, 4/5>?
The directional derivative is maximized when moving in the direction of the gradient.
questions.explanation: D_u f = ∇f · u = |∇f|cos(θ) is maximized when θ = 0, i.e., when u points in the direction of ∇f

questions.prompt: What is the normal line to the surface z = x² + y² at point (1,1,2)?
questions.explanation: Normal vector is <f_x, f_y, -1> = <2x, 2y, -1> = <2, 2, -1> at (1,1,2). Normal line: r₀ + tn

questions.prompt: For the surface x² + y² + z² = 9, what is the gradient at point (2,2,1)?
questions.explanation: Let F = x² + y² + z² - 9. Then ∇F = <2x, 2y, 2z> = <4, 4, 2> at (2,2,1)
